newsitem.title: HONG KONG: FEATURE-HK "Pillar of Shame" first meant for Oklah.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE-HK "Pillar of Shame" first meant for Oklah.

text.p: Pain contorts
the 50 or so faces depicted in Hong Kong's "Pillar of Shame", a focus for China democracy campaigners, but something else catches the eye.

Bystanders are puzzled, because the writhing victims mainly do not resemble Asians, raising a question whether the Danish artist had China in mind when he carved features that he says symbolise oppression by Beijing.
Banned from Hong Kong's public parks in the weeks before the handover to Beijing's rule, the "Pillar of Shame" has been praised and denounced here as an artistic political symbol.

It became a centre-piece of this year's Tiananmen massacre commemoration in Hong Kong, which drew 55,000 people to a candle-lit vigil, amid concern about the future of civil liberties under Chinese rule.

The statue, excluded from civic areas by legislators who called it "terrible" and lacking in beauty, has been permitted to stand for two weeks on an isolated university campus after demands by student demonstrators.

In a strange irony, it now seems that this icon for current anti-China protests was once meant for Oklahoma City in the United States, target of a terrorist attack that fearful Americans originally blamed on foreign groups.

According to the 43-year-old artist Jens Galschiot, of Odense, the eight-metre (26 feet) grey tower of twisted bodies was built for Oklahoma City after a bomb in a federal government building killed 168 people in April, 1995.
OKLAHOMA CITY WAS FIRST CHOICE
"Oklahoma City was the first choice," he said in an interview. "I was afraid if I put a political sculpture in Asia people might see me as imperialist with double standards."
Galschiot used fewer than eight Oriental models for the pillar, with the others mostly Europeans.
Some Hong Kong residents have wondered why the Pillar contained so many Caucasian-looking faces.
This was the second of up to 20 such pillars he wanted to make and place all over the world, the next one being in Russia's war-torn Chechnya region. The first one was an exhibition piece in Rome.
"The Pillar of Shame is about the discussions of the right wing in the United States that produce the kind of people who bomb their own people," Galschiot said.
Defence attorneys for the convicted bomber Timothy McVeigh, who may face the death penalty for the Oklahoma attack, say the ex-soldier thought the U.S. government was at war with the American people.

When Galschiot found the U.S. government had already commissioned another piece for Oklahoma, he then considered Hong Kong, the British colony on the southern edge of China, as a site for his political artwork.
Now, just weeks before July 1, when China retakes Hong Kong, the sculpture is hailed here as a symbol of the June 4, 1989 Tiananmen massacre by Chinese soldiers of hundreds of pro-democracy students.
ORIGINS AROUSE MIXED FEELINGS

"I do not think (initial intentions to put the sculpture in Oklahoma) would affect the symbolism because Galschiot said he would send it to wherever there is suppression of human rights," said Szeto Wah, leader of the Hong Kong Alliance in support of Patriotic Democratic Movements in China.
Democrats and hundreds of Hong Kong students who fought for a home for the sculpture in Hong Kong's public area may have different feelings.
"The fact that the pillar was intended for Oklahoma makes us feel betrayed," said one Hong Kong University activist.
Hong Kong University officials overturned an earlier ban and agreed to allow the sculpture on campus for two weeks, after about 500 students protested when authorities blocked its way.
Civic authorities refused to allow the sculpture to remain in public parks after a brief appearance on June 4.

Some art critics have reservations about the pillar. "I do not think this is great art because it is very sensational, but it uses the event very successfully," Lau Kin Wai, a freelance art commmentator, said.
The fibre-clay sculpture, which cost HK$1 million (US$128,000), is not for sale --"It is a gift to the Chinese people."
Galschiot, whose birthday coincides with the Tiananmen anniversary, says: "This was my best birthday, because the candle light vigil was the strongest demonstration I have ever seen," he said.
